thread.title: Heavy surf prompts nearly 200 rescues over two days in Ocean City
thread.title_full: Heavy surf prompts nearly 200 rescues over two days in Ocean City

author: Scott Dance
title: Heavy surf prompts nearly 200 rescues over two days in Ocean City
text:
Swimming Sunday was a busy day for Ocean City lifeguards, and a dangerous one for swimmers. 
Ocean City lifeguards made nearly 200 rescues Sunday and Monday, including more than a dozen while they were off duty, as heavy surf pounded the beach and caused dangerous rip currents. 
Several swimmers had to be hospitalized, and an ambulance was called for three people who were pushed against rocks while swimming after lifeguards left for the evening Sunday, said Butch Arbin, captain of the Ocean City Beach Patrol. Caption Ocean City Beach Patrol Barbara Haddock Taylor, Baltimore Sun 
Tim Uebel, center, a sergeant with the Ocean City Beach Patrol, gives training to new lifeguards for helping victims of neck and back injuries received in the surf. 
Tim Uebel, center, a sergeant with the Ocean City Beach Patrol, gives training to new lifeguards for helping victims of neck and back injuries received in the surf. (Barbara Haddock Taylor, Baltimore Sun) Caption Ocean City Beach Patrol Barbara Haddock Taylor, Baltimore Sun 
Members of the Ocean City Beach Patrol receive training on "neck and back extraction" of people whose necks and backs have been injured in the surf. 
Members of the Ocean City Beach Patrol receive training on "neck and back extraction" of people whose necks and backs have been injured in the surf. (Barbara Haddock Taylor, Baltimore Sun) See more galleries 
On Monday, rip currents continued to prompt lifeguards to intervene, though no major incidents were reported. In most rescues, swimmers are not in distress but were at risk of being pulled away from shore by a rip current, Arbin said. 
"If the person doesn't respond to the whistle and flags, then the lifeguard will make a rescue," Arbin said. "Most of them were the more preventative type of rescues." 
Forecasts suggest the seas will start to calm Tuesday.
